Massachusetts General Laws c. 231, \u00a.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 231, §1.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 223, \u00a.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 223, §2, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the property at issue is located within this Court’s jurisdiction.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, which prohibits a landlord from interfering substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental property.

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 93A, \u00a79.proposition: 7. Mass. Gen. Laws c. 93A, §9 (references to unfair and deceptive practices where relevant here).

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, \u00a7\u00a71, 2.proposition: 10. Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, §§1, 2 (jurisdiction and venue).

*Dolan v. Coleman*, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 10.raw_text: *Dolan v. Coleman*, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 104, 463 N.E.2d 1191 (1984).
*Dolan v. Coleman*, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 10.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, which prohibits a landlord from interfering substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental property.
*Dolan v. Coleman*, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 10.case_name: Ogden Suffolk Downs, Inc. v. City of Boston
*Dolan v. Coleman*, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 10.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text in Dolan v. Coleman concerns the interpretation and retroactive application of a Massachusetts tax interest statute (G. L. c. 59, § 69, as amended by St. 1980, c. 406). It does not discuss landlord–tenant law, residential leases, or the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under G. L. c. 186, § 14. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the claimed proposition about implied covenants of quiet enjoyment in residential leases.
*Dolan v. Coleman*, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 10.relevant_excerpt: The racetrack’s contention is that, by virtue of the revision of G. L. c. 59, § 69, by St. 1980, c. 406, § 1, it is entitled to interest at the rate of eight percent, (instead of six percent) on the abatement ordered by the Board. Section 1 of c. 406 revised § 69 to read, “Section 69. A person whose tax has been abated shall, if the tax has been paid, be reimbursed by the town to the amount of the abatement allowed, including all interest and all charges paid therewith . . . with interest on the amount so abated at eight per cent from the time of payment or the due date of the tax, whichever is later ...” (emphasis supplied).

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 679.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, which prohibits a landlord from interfering substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental property.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 679.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that G.L. c. 186, § 14 “codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment,” and then discusses when landlord conduct violates that statutory covenant. While the case’s main issue is whether a lead-paint violation automatically breaches § 14, the court clearly recognizes the existence of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases and describes it as prohibiting landlord interference (at least negligent) with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Thus it directly supports the proposition about the statutory implied covenant and substantial interference standard.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 679.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises…. Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, which prohibits a landlord from interfering substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental property.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N..support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts residential tenancies and ties it to G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court explains that “[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant” of quiet enjoyment and that § 14 imposes liability on landlords who “directly or indirectly interfere” with that quiet enjoyment, thus confirming both the implied covenant in every residential lease and that substantial landlord interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment is prohibited by the statute.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 431 N..relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 576.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, which prohibits a landlord from interfering substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental property.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 576.support_reasoning:
The opinion involves a counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the reproduced portion focuses on recusal, Chapter 93A emotional distress damages, and warranty of habitability damages. It neither states that every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment nor discusses the nature or statutory codification of that covenant. Because the text provided does not analyze or even describe the quiet enjoyment claim or § 14’s substantive rule, this case excerpt does not clearly support the specific proposition.

A more complete version of the opinion or other Massachusetts cases (e.g., Hemingway, or cases directly construing c. 186, § 14) would be better authority for that proposition.

*Warsame v. Bridgeview Prop. Mgmt., LLC*.raw_text: *Warsame v. Bridgeview Prop. Mgmt., LLC*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 120, 57 N.E.3d 656 (2016).
*Warsame v. Bridgeview Prop. Mgmt., LLC*.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, which prohibits a landlord from interfering substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental property.
*Warsame v. Bridgeview Prop. Mgmt., LLC*.case_name: Zoning Board of Appeals of Hanover v. Housing Appeals Committee
*Warsame v. Bridgeview Prop. Mgmt., LLC*.support_reasoning: This opinion is a zoning/Chapter 40B case about filing fees, completeness of a comprehensive permit application, and regulatory safe harbor status. It does not involve residential leases, landlord-tenant law, or the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that every residential lease in Massachusetts contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibiting substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of rental property.

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.raw_text: *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, 293 N.E.2d 831 (1973).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, which prohibits a landlord from interfering substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental property.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This passage is a separate opinion (concurring in part and dissenting in part) and does not itself articulate or apply an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Justice Quirico instead discusses implied warranty/habitability concepts and statutory housing standards, and expressly distances himself from some of the majority’s broader doctrinal moves. Because this text neither grounds nor interprets c. 186, § 14, it cannot accurately be cited as authority for the proposition that every residential lease contains the statutory implied covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibiting substantial interference with use and enjoyment.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: "As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards."}

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 835 N.E.2d 705 (2005).
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, which prohibits a landlord from interfering substantially with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental property.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that during the rental of any residential premises there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment, and cites Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, § 14 as the statutory basis. It further describes that covenant as protecting the tenant from serious interference with her tenancy, which aligns with the proposition’s characterization of substantial interference with use and enjoyment. Thus, the case directly supports the stated legal principle under Massachusetts law.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy.”
